metadata.sermon_title: Philadelphia: The Keepers Are Kept, Part 1
metadata.notes: The sermon addresses a congregation during a period of racial tension and the 1980s drug epidemic.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. The preacher avoids 'shaming' and instead uses self-inclusion ('we') to soften demands.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: Coercion is replaced by moral invitation. Even when challenging the congregation on racial voting patterns, he includes himself in the guilt.
quotes: If it serves you well, then who am I to say nay to this?

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. High score due to the preacher's validation of the listener's small efforts.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The Nurturing Parent is used to empower rather than create dependency. He validates their 'little strength' as sufficient.
quotes: How patiently the Lord has dealt with us, and what weak people we are.
You don't have to give them your name, and if nothing happens you call me.

adult.score_explanation: 10 = Strong Adult presence. The preacher uses historical data, etymology, and logical comparisons.
adult.analysis: The preacher engages the listener's intellect by analyzing budget figures ($65b vs $3b) and Greek etymology. He invites the listener to 'get the difference' between two interpretations.
quotes: I wanted to find out from where it came. Now, there are forms of patience that I do not take to be referred to here.
Why then are we so upset with them because they would not give a black candidate more than 13 percent when we would not give a white more than 3 or 4 percent?

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. The preacher models an independent stance against political and social pressure.
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The preacher refuses to adapt to the 'inflammatory rhetoric' of the time, choosing instead a path of nuanced reconciliation.
quotes: I am almost embarrassed to say it, but there it stands in the Scripture.
That word patience has always troubled me.

free_child_FC.score_explanation: 10 = Authentic, playful, joyful. The preacher shows authentic nostalgia and personal warmth.
free_child_FC.analysis: The Free Child appears in the nostalgic opening about his first church and the use of the 'Green Pastures' anecdote.
quotes: It was a joy to go into that church that evening after forty years.
I ain't much, but I'se all you got.

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher consistently treats the congregation as capable of logical reflection and moral autonomy. He presents data (voting percentages, drug trade stats) and asks the congregation to process it.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: Minimal. The preacher is remarkably transparent about his own biases and struggles with the text.
transaction_analysis.purity_explanation: 10 = Completely transparent. The preacher avoids the 'holier-than-thou' trap by admitting his own failings.
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The only slight risk of an ulterior transaction is the 'I'll help you' offer regarding the police, which could lean toward a Rescuer role, but it is framed as a partnership.

detected_games.name: None
evidence_quotes: If you have to believe that... hold on to it. But you must not read the New Testament.

games_analysis.absence_of_games_analysis: The preacher avoids 'Ain't It Awful' by moving immediately from the problem (drugs/racism) to concrete, small-scale Adult actions. He avoids 'NIGYSOB' by including himself in the critique of voting patterns.

preacher_roles.rescuer: Low. He offers to call the police for them, but emphasizes their own agency first.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Very Low. He critiques the 'body politic' but remains empathetic to the congregation.
preacher_roles.victim: Low. He mentions being 'troubled' by the word patience, but uses it as a catalyst for study rather than a bid for pity.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: The congregation is invited into the Adult roleâ€”as partners in 'using what little strength we do have.'
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: The sermon is an escape from the triangle. It moves the listener from 'Victim' (helpless against $65b drug trade) to 'Adult' (can call the police or educate a child).

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: This sermon is a model of psychologically healthy communication. It avoids the common homiletical trap of the Critical Parent (shaming the congregation for not being 'holy' enough) and instead uses the Adult ego state to analyze reality. By admitting his own prejudices and 'little strength,' the preacher levels the playing field, creating a safe space for the congregation to exercise their own autonomy. The focus on 'little strength' vs 'no strength' is a powerful move to pull the listeners out of a 'Victim' position in the Drama Triangle.
strengths: High level of self-disclosure and vulnerability.
Use of Adult data to challenge emotional biases.
Empowerment of the listener through small, achievable goals.
areas_for_improvement: The 'I will get in touch with that police official' could slightly foster dependency if not careful.
The transition between the drug trade and the Jewish community's voting is a bit abrupt.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Continue using 'we' instead of 'you' when discussing moral failings. Keep providing the 'Adult' data (etymology, statistics) as it grounds the 'Parental' moral imperatives in reality.
